text: I don't think there's anything wrong
with media today um maybe the the thing
that's been wrong in general is that
we've been so locked into um definitions
of what the medium is and I'm thinking
in particular of paper produced by wood
pulp uh that you know we forget to focus
on what really matters which is the
quality content so you know everyone is
quick to record the demise of some very
well-known papers around the world but
you know where is the sidebar that you
know looks at what you guys are doing
here in big think um some of the really
interesting Electronic Services the
growth of blogs um it's not all just a
question of
there's this wonderful um historically
important newspaper content which is
going away and everything else is
amateur rubbish um you know I see a the
normal process of creative destruction
going on and a group of people in
control of um sort of the
commentariat um lovingly holding on to
Wood pulp based newsprint and making the
assumption that all journalism dies if
that form of paper dies and I I just
fundamentally don't buy that
connection so I was um I was actually at
an off the Record um sort of gathering
of a group of really um clever people
who get together once a month in dumbo
in in Brooklyn to Envision what given
Industries might might be like 30 years
out it's a group called y + 30 um run by
a friend of mine Named Sam Lon and I was
asked to come and talk about financial
information markets and we talked about
that and then of course the conversation
turned to media and newspapers as it
tends to and it is an interesting
subject so I was asked you know what
would newspapers be like in 30 years and
to be provocative I began to ask the
question well you know why does the New
York Times need 600 or a
thousand uh journalists if you were
starting today would you build such a
really vertically integrated operation
or could you imagine a new definition of
a quality newspaper where you said okay
I really want to read the Times about
what's going on in New York I want to
read the Times about Israel I want to
read the Times on International I
certainly want to read Tom Freeman but
do I really need to get my sports
coverage from the times do I need to get
my business coverage from the times um
and if you start down that road you
quickly might ask well I'd probably be
pretty happy with Sports Illustrated or
ESPN providing the sports coverage and
Thompson Reuters or Dow Jones supplying
the business coverage um why do we have
to think of a newspaper as a as a brand
of content covering every element no
other business works that way right so
when I fly on American Airlines um they
say on the menu we proudly feature
Starbucks Coffee well that's actually a
pretty good thing because I think
American Airlines coffee is lousy
Starbucks is a bit better and so I'm
even happier about that now if they told
me that Starbucks Baristas were doing
engine maintenance or flying the plane I
wouldn't be happy so I think it's a
question of just exactly the same thing
which all of us in business have had to
do for years which is understand what
our core competencies are understand
where we add value and where we don't um
Thompson Reuters used to we used to
build our own Hardware we used to build
our own operating systems we used to
operate our own private um
Communications networks I mean you
technically can do lots of things the
question is do you really need to and
what would you need to
retain um to to Really own um to be true
to the character and full potential of
what your brand is about and so with
that as context and I granted it's not a
a little sound bite um I asked the
question well what if you took the 30
very best journalists at the New York
Times and I recognize that you'd
probably need a farm club system so you
can't just take all the people that are
growing up now how do you develop Talent
so throw in another 30 or throw in
another 60 however many you want
couldn't you grow something truly
fantastic of course you wouldn't have um
paper distribution why would you ever
bother 30 years out so I could easily
imagine a New York Times uh with 100
employees just as if you were starting
out in the film uh the photo business um
you could invent flicker instead of
invite inventing Eastman Kodak with
10,000 people in Rochester New York um
but of course because it involves a
newspaper and an icon like the times it
sort of sends titillating shock waves
across the commentariat but it really
shouldn't
